instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Odd <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Behavior
threads.message:
Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has a backlight issue; it's minor, and one I normally would not worry about, but the customer sent it in so I'm going to try:

1. <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with backlight issue: Backlight does not turn on until board reaches OSX login screen. Behavior is 100% consistent, every time.
2. Have tried several displays.
3. No liquid damage at all.
4. Tried a new BIOS and LED driver to be safe, no change.
5. Continuity everywhere and all is well from what I can tell, but the board will not output backlight until it reaches login screen. So if you want to boot from external drive, you can't see anything without shining a light at screen, etc.
6. Once booted, boards works perfectly fine. Sleep/wake is fine.
7. Passes AHT fine.
8. Diode readings across all pins of eDP are fine.

Any clue where to start with this one? I was thinking maybe a backlight clock/data/smbus issue, but everything checks out. Behavior is consistent across multiple panels. New BIOS and BIOS update via HS (.B00) results in no change. No idea where to go with this one.

As always, any and all help appreciated.

threads.title: Odd <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Behavior
threads.message: Did you even try a PRAM reset????

threads.title: Odd <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Behavior
threads.message: Of course, I "even" tried a PRAM reset ("????"--condescension noted). I tried an entirely new BIOS, which I'd hope would lead you to assume something as trivial as a PRAM reset did not resolve the issue. If it helps, I also tried turning the unit on and off again.

threads.title: Odd <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Behavior
threads.message: Lol was just asking because it was not mentioned in the above post...Any history liquid drop etc?

threads.title: Odd <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Behavior
threads.message: Got this one resolved; <CHIP>U8310</CHIP> had a BGA pad (pin 2) loose/detached on it. It measured fine and reflowed fine, but once replaced board is giving backlight properly/immediately. Pad came right off when removed it. Thanks!
